text: President Barack Obama is asking the
Environmental Protection Agency today to
reconsider California's desire to
increase emission standards for cars i'm
here with andy Revkin to ask him a
little bit about the implications of
that decision so Andy can you give us a
little bit of background about this
particular decision and California's
desire I know they've been wanting to
have this for a long time yeah well
California has for decades had a pattern
of moving out ahead of the federal
government on clean air standards and
they have they won the right to do that
a long time ago and they now feel under
Governor Schwarzenegger that okay co2
carbon dioxide is just as legitimate a
pollutant something to regulate as the
old stuff that we've cleaned up with
other mechanisms and this has been
several years in the making they've been
pushing the auto industry has been
fighting in court in California and also
resisting through pressure in Washington
the Bush administration resisted this
relentlessly and they always were trying
to portray Auto efficiency as a federal
initiative unrelated to climate are
there concerns legitimate in that the
auto industry is I understand it will
often say that they drought they'd
rather not have to deal with a number of
statewide initiatives because it would
be incredibly difficult and complex to
manufacture to multiple standards is
that a legitimate concern of theirs or I
saw one figure where something like
forty percent of america's car market
already is kind of signed on in a way in
theory so there that will lead
inevitably to what this has happened
under the Clean Air Act as well the this
big expanding push among the states
leads to some federal resolution in the
end so is this a bold move by the
administration or is it something that
we thought was going to come it really
was the kind of thing that most
everybody expected he had laid out but
his intention to do this it overall it's
seen as low fruit I think signing a
piece of paper is different than pushing
forward with Congress to write a new bit
of legislation California now will face
its own hurdles and trying to move this
forward in court for sure but it was the
kind of thing that on anyone's list as
you head toward a world in a country
that's going to be less dependent on
fuels and producing fewer emissions with
a growing economy we need the new
technologies and we'll need cleaner cars
it's that simple so everyone to sort of
said it's an inevitable so what does
this say in kind of we were able to step
back a bit what does this say about
Barack Obama and the new
administration's approach to climate
change in general he's made it clear
that despite the political inconvenience
of dealing with things like higher
energy standards for cars even if it
makes them a little more expensive even
amid an economic a time of economic
retrenchment he's saying this is a
sustained priority for him and he's
already shown this potential ability to
kind of stick with something he thinks
it's important even when it's
politically inconvenient so it is Obama
proving to be our first truly green
president well that's that's how an
interesting question you know Richard
Nixon could probably support us of Nixon
could say he was our first green
President Teddy Roosevelt I guess you
could say he could be in the pantheon of
presidents who did things like create
the EPA which Nixon did or push ahead on
a big parks program like Roosevelt did
the potential is there
